update.description:
**This is mainly here to remind me to finish testing this**

Added tentative support for the Cicero pseudoclock that uses an Opal Kelly XEM3001 FPGA development board.

Firmware \(.bit files\) for the FPGA are available from [https://bitbucket.org/labscript\_suite/opalkellyxem3001/](#!/labscript_suite/opalkellyxem3001) and should be placed in the labscript\_devices folder for this to work. You also need to install the Opal Kelly SDK, which provides python bindings, and these Python bindings will need to be manually copied into the site-packages of any virtual environments you want to run BLACS from.

Things that need more testing:

* Using the external reference
* The inbuilt wait monitor
* That it can be substituted for another pseudoclock and the experiment sequence still has the same result \(aka, I’ve implemented it correctly!\)
update.title: Cicero Opal Kelly XEM3001 pseudoclock

content.raw: Well it would have been triggered by the zero crossing of a 50Hz sine wave, so presumably sometimes it happened fast. I suspect it accounts for the dropped shots in the spinor lab.
content.html: Well it would have been triggered by the zero crossing of a 50Hz sine wave, so presumably sometimes it happened fast. I suspect it accounts for the dropped shots in the spinor lab.

content.raw:
Note to self: Add support for dynamic timebase.

While the PLL seems to default to the internal clock ticking at 100MHz, this can be adjusted. Also, there is no requirement on the external reference frequency \(except that presumably it has an upper limit somewhere…\). So these need to be able to be specified in the constructor in labscript, and stored somewhere \(as it affects measuring the length of waits\). A further consequence of this is all of the timing delays are actually just multiple of the reference \(at least from my reading of the FPGA code\) so they should be defined as such. Not sure how easy it is to dynamically set some of these though, so need to investigate it!
content.html:
Note to self: Add support for dynamic timebase.

While the PLL seems to default to the internal clock ticking at 100MHz, this can be adjusted. Also, there is no requirement on the external reference frequency (except that presumably it has an upper limit somewhere…). So these need to be able to be specified in the constructor in labscript, and stored somewhere (as it affects measuring the length of waits). A further consequence of this is all of the timing delays are actually just multiple of the reference (at least from my reading of the FPGA code) so they should be defined as such. Not sure how easy it is to dynamically set some of these though, so need to investigate it!

content.raw:
> So does that mean that it doesn’t matter if you overestimate the value a bit?

Sounds correct to me! In labscript 3 I'm adding a global configuration parameter for how much all of them should be overestimated experiment-wide, kind of a tolerance for the fact that you have not calibrated all the delays in all your cables so you want to err on the side of caution.

> Also, the PseudoclockDevice.trigger() method is never called with a wait_delay.

Hm. Might be a bug. 

> Output.wait_delay doesn't appear to be used anywhere either (everything uses compiler.wait_delay).
 
I think this one is for the user's sake, so that they can t+= output.wait_delay() to ensure they don't command output before it is possible after a wait.

> This might actually explain why a few years ago I saw secondary PulseBlasters occasionally not be retriggered correctly after a wait.

Maybe! Would had to have been a very fast trigger though, since the PulseBlasters are quick to be ready for retriggering - the pineblaster on the other hand I think is up to 4us before it can be ready for a retriggering.

It looks like it might not be a quick fix to just trigger the secondary pseudoclocks later, as the instruction offsetting doesn't look like it is taking into account this delay, and it would need to to be consistent.

I wouldn't mind ignoring the problem for now, as this is the kind of thing that is more carefully considered in labscript 3 (which I'll get back to working on after the great Spielman fork/mainline convergence).
content.html:
So does that mean that it doesn’t matter if you overestimate the value a bit?

Sounds correct to me! In labscript 3 I'm adding a global configuration parameter for how much all of them should be overestimated experiment-wide, kind of a tolerance for the fact that you have not calibrated all the delays in all your cables so you want to err on the side of caution.

Also, the PseudoclockDevice.trigger() method is never called with a wait_delay.

Hm. Might be a bug.

Output.wait_delay doesn't appear to be used anywhere either (everything uses compiler.wait_delay).

I think this one is for the user's sake, so that they can t+= output.wait_delay() to ensure they don't command output before it is possible after a wait.

This might actually explain why a few years ago I saw secondary PulseBlasters occasionally not be retriggered correctly after a wait.

Maybe! Would had to have been a very fast trigger though, since the PulseBlasters are quick to be ready for retriggering - the pineblaster on the other hand I think is up to 4us before it can be ready for a retriggering.

It looks like it might not be a quick fix to just trigger the secondary pseudoclocks later, as the instruction offsetting doesn't look like it is taking into account this delay, and it would need to to be consistent.

I wouldn't mind ignoring the problem for now, as this is the kind of thing that is more carefully considered in labscript 3 (which I'll get back to working on after the great Spielman fork/mainline convergence).

content.raw:
So does that mean that it doesn’t matter if you overestimate the value a bit?

Also, the `PseudoclockDevice.trigger()` method is never called with a `wait_delay`.  And `Output.wait_delay` doesn't appear to be used anywhere either \(everything uses `compiler.wait_delay`\). I suspect this means the code is not actually doing what those comments imply \(which is why I'm confused\). It seems like for a secondary pseudoclock, the `wait_delay` should determine the minimum wait length \(if my understanding of what you said is correct\), but I think it's not because it isn't being passed to `trigger` when it is called [here](#!/labscript_suite/labscript/src/fa1636c366f2200c907a56b0106306b7e2ce5109/labscript.py#lines-2152).

This might actually explain why a few years ago I saw secondary PulseBlasters occasionally not be retriggered correctly after a wait.
content.html:
So does that mean that it doesn’t matter if you overestimate the value a bit?

Also, the PseudoclockDevice.trigger() method is never called with a wait_delay. And Output.wait_delay doesn't appear to be used anywhere either (everything uses compiler.wait_delay). I suspect this means the code is not actually doing what those comments imply (which is why I'm confused). It seems like for a secondary pseudoclock, the wait_delay should determine the minimum wait length (if my understanding of what you said is correct), but I think it's not because it isn't being passed to trigger when it is called here.

This might actually explain why a few years ago I saw secondary PulseBlasters occasionally not be retriggered correctly after a wait.

content.raw:
The comment in the code for the class attribute of `PseudoclockDevice`is:

```python
# How long after the start of a wait instruction the device is actually capable of resuming:
```
And later in the property `wait_delay` of `Output`:
```python
    @property
    def wait_delay(self):
        """The earliest time output can be commanded from this device after a wait.
        This is nonzeo on secondary pseudoclocks due to triggering delays and the fact
        that the master clock doesn't provide a resume trigger to secondary clocks until
        a minimum time has elapsed: compiler.wait_delay. This is so that if a wait is 
        extremely short, the child clock is actually ready for the trigger.
        """
```

So it looks wait_delay on a PseudoclockDevice is how long it takes to enter a wait state, whereas on an Output it is that, plus any triggering delays due to them being on a secondary pseudoclock. It looks like the PseudoclockDevice attribute is used to ensure that the master pseudoclock does not give resume triggers to secondary pseudoclocks too soon, since they may not be ready yet. Then the result (plus the max trigger delay) is returned by `wait()` so that the user knows how long until it is safe to command output from any device. The wait delay and trigger delay of the master pseudoclock don't count, they are not part of 'labscript time', so this is just about secondary pseudoclocks.

So bottom line is: it's how long the device takes to become sensitive to triggers after hitting a wait instruction.
content.html:
The comment in the code for the class attribute of PseudoclockDeviceis:

# How long after the start of a wait instruction the device is actually capable of resuming:

And later in the property wait_delay of Output:

    @property
    def wait_delay(self):
        """The earliest time output can be commanded from this device after a wait.
        This is nonzeo on secondary pseudoclocks due to triggering delays and the fact
        that the master clock doesn't provide a resume trigger to secondary clocks until
        a minimum time has elapsed: compiler.wait_delay. This is so that if a wait is 
        extremely short, the child clock is actually ready for the trigger.
        """

So it looks wait_delay on a PseudoclockDevice is how long it takes to enter a wait state, whereas on an Output it is that, plus any triggering delays due to them being on a secondary pseudoclock. It looks like the PseudoclockDevice attribute is used to ensure that the master pseudoclock does not give resume triggers to secondary pseudoclocks too soon, since they may not be ready yet. Then the result (plus the max trigger delay) is returned by wait() so that the user knows how long until it is safe to command output from any device. The wait delay and trigger delay of the master pseudoclock don't count, they are not part of 'labscript time', so this is just about secondary pseudoclocks.

So bottom line is: it's how long the device takes to become sensitive to triggers after hitting a wait instruction.

content.raw:
@cbillington I still have a bit more testing to do, but could you confirm what `wait_delay` is? Is it how long the wait instruction lasts for after a trigger is received? Or how long it takes for the device to enter a wait?

It only seems to be used in calculating the return value of a call to `wait()`, and in a couple of checks for errant instructions so I was unsure.
content.html:
@cbillington I still have a bit more testing to do, but could you confirm what wait_delay is? Is it how long the wait instruction lasts for after a trigger is received? Or how long it takes for the device to enter a wait?

It only seems to be used in calculating the return value of a call to wait(), and in a couple of checks for errant instructions so I was unsure.

update.description:
**This is mainly here to remind me to finish testing this**

Added tentative support for the Cicero pseudoclock that uses an Opal Kelly XEM3001 FPGA development board.

Firmware \(.bit files\) for the FPGA are available from [https://bitbucket.org/labscript\_suite/opalkellyxem3001/](#!/labscript_suite/opalkellyxem3001/) and should be placed in the labscript\_devices folder for this to work. You also need to install the Opal Kelly SDK, which provides python bindings, and these Python bindings will need to be manually copied into the site-packages of any virtual environments you want to run BLACS from.

Things that need more testing:

* Using the external reference
* The inbuilt wait monitor
* That it can be substituted for another pseudoclock and the experiment sequence still has the same result \(aka, I’ve implemented it correctly!\)
update.title: Cicero Opal Kelly XEM3001 pseudoclock

content.raw:
Good point. I’ve added it \(untested for now\).

P.S. This device is not as fast, and is more expensive than the one Rory is developing with, so this pull request shouldn’t discourage him from porting his FPGA device to labscript! I wrote this about 3 years ago, mainly to try and help Martijn move away from Cicero, but just never pushed it to a repo until now.
content.html:
Good point. I’ve added it (untested for now).

P.S. This device is not as fast, and is more expensive than the one Rory is developing with, so this pull request shouldn’t discourage him from porting his FPGA device to labscript! I wrote this about 3 years ago, mainly to try and help Martijn move away from Cicero, but just never pushed it to a repo until now.
